header_summary:
Recent discussions within the Bitcoin development community, as exemplified by /dev /fd0 and others, have predominantly focused on enhancing Bitcoin's contract efficiency through innovations such as Resumeable LN channels, Multi-party LN channels, and Vaults. These discussions also highlight a broader debate regarding the necessity of certain opcodes, with efforts to change opinions through development tools like an [activation client](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/c411dee9-1937-42fd-bc66-d347ddbff506n@googlegroups.com/T/#mb3c337420fd3f94cbc1d3699bd0a41b000f210d8) and comparison tables.

In another vein, Ian Quantum underscores the urgency of migrating Bitcoin to quantum-resistant protocols in light of rapid advancements in quantum computing, evidenced by the breakthrough algorithm from Alice and Bob capable of breaking ECC-256 encryption within hours. This narrative is supported by NIST's formalization of post-quantum cryptographic standards and the development of a quantum-safe FIPS, marking significant progress despite challenges in ecosystem update and user migration ([NIST Announcement](https://csrc.nist.gov/News/2024/postquantum-cryptography-fips-approved)).

Furthermore, the Bitcoin community is exploring novel approaches to enhance network resilience against censorship and control. A proposal detailed by an anonymous developer focuses on leveraging the "nLockTime" feature to prioritize transactions in the mempool, advocating for a dual sorting mechanism that balances transaction fee rates with timestamps. This concept aims to ensure fairness and efficiency in transaction processing without introducing new system elements ([detailed discussion on nLockTime](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/f1a0153b-3142-4e01-a68e-92c458762b89@dashjr.org/T/#m79b93d3c8f40715707d41cd1b4a2e8158496005e)).

Additionally, the discourse extends into the realm of cryptographic standards development, with cryptoquick and others debating the integration of new algorithms into high assurance products and BIP-360's potential alignment with DASK for hybrid cryptography. This reflects a careful, collaborative approach to evolving Bitcoin's cryptographic underpinnings in anticipation of quantum computing challenges, as seen in the latest iteration of [BIP-360](https://github.com/cryptoquick/bips/blob/0ae69db70a4a28f202d441b7131cd5b2169e7afe/bip-0360.mediawiki).

recent_posts.title: Trivial QC signatures with clean upgrade path
recent_posts.summary:
- FALCON failed NIST vetting since 2022, with ongoing yearly promises for resolution.
- NIST formalized CRYSTALS standards and develops FIPS with FALCON-derived digital signature.
- Quantum computing advances necessitate swift migration to quantum-resistant cryptographic standards.

recent_posts.title: Mandatory Inclusion of Old Transactions in Blocks
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal enhances Bitcoin's resilience by utilizing "nLockTime" to prioritize transactions.
- A dual sorting mechanism in the mempool would balance transaction fee rate and "nLockTime".
- This method aims for fairness, giving older, lower-fee transactions a better inclusion chance.

recent_posts.title: End of 2024 site statistics
recent_posts.summary:
- Daily logged-in user visits to the delving website grew from 22 to 1315 over two years.
- An upgrade in mid-2024 aimed to improve handling of automated traffic, enhancing visit quality.
- Changes in content generation may influence user visit patterns, though specifics weren't detailed.

recent_posts.title: Contract-level Relative Timelocks
recent_posts.summary:
- Contract-level Relative Timelock (CLRT) UTXO addresses ln-symmetry issues in Eltoo constructs.
- Proposed solution changes transaction sequence to include a "kickoff" with CLRT for settlement precondition.
- Challenges include transaction cost, technical complexity, and proof maintenance with potential simplifications via Chia's coinid.

recent_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
recent_posts.summary:
- The email discusses adopting new algorithms in high assurance products cautiously.
- It explores updating BIP-360 with WOTS and testing attestation disambiguation methods.
- There's interest in hybrid cryptography and incorporating DASK into BIP-360's latest iteration.

active_posts.title: Trivial QC signatures with clean upgrade path
active_posts.summary:
- Debate highlights need to upgrade Bitcoin's security against quantum computing threats.
- Community favors hash-based signatures like SPHINCS/SPHINCS+ for post-quantum security in Bitcoin.
- Proposed solution includes using taproot for quantum-resistant transactions but poses confiscation risks.

active_posts.title: Summary: Covenants Support - Bitcoin Wiki
active_posts.summary:
- Significant updates to the covenants support wiki were informed to Bitcoin developers in November 2024.
- Feedback from Murch and Gloria on Bitcoin Optech podcast influenced a dedicated page for use cases and prototypes.
- A call for technical consensus among developers emphasized engaging discussions and workshops for covenant refinements.

active_posts.title: Mandatory Inclusion of Old Transactions in Blocks
active_posts.summary:
- This proposal mandates Bitcoin miners to include 0.1% oldest transactions in each block.
- It aims to combat mining centralization and ensure democratic transaction processing.
- The adoption of this proposal is pivotal for maintaining Bitcoin's decentralization and fairness.

active_posts.title: CTV, APO, CAT activity on signet
active_posts.summary:
- BIPs 118, 119, and 347 bring new scripting capabilities to Bitcoin on signet.
- Observations show APO used mostly for coinbase transactions and CTV for complex spend conditions.
- OP_CAT's usage, largely for Proof of Work processes, surpasses APO and CTV in transactions.

active_posts.title: Fastest-possible PoW via Simple DAG
active_posts.summary:
- Braidpool's new difficulty algorithm achieves consensus without traditional metrics, targeting DAG width.
- The optimal DAG width of 1 allows unanimous agreement among nodes, expediting consensus.
- This algorithm's efficiency and speed outperform other systems, presenting a promising blockchain evolution.

active_posts.title: Transitory Soft Forks for Consensus Cleanup Forks
active_posts.summary:
- Soft forks may now have "shelf lives" to ensure temporary protocol adjustments in blockchain.
- This approach allows for the reversal of changes if future technologies provide better solutions.
- It differentiates between adding new features and making consensus cleanups for system security.

today_in_history_posts.title: Time to worry about 80-bit collision attacks or not?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Gavin Andresen discussed security versus efficiency in Bitcoin's segregated witness proposal.
- He suggested contract wallets could mitigate collision attacks, deeming extra storage trivial.
- Andresen concluded emphasizing security over efficiency despite the low risk of brute-force attacks.

today_in_history_posts.title: Deflationary money is a Good Thing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Passive and active investments represent two primary financial strategies with distinct management levels.

- It suggests central banks could stabilize economies using a mix of deflationary and inflationary currencies.
